awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Smartphone Incentive System to Align Electricity Demand with Intermittent Supply
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Program (SBIR) Phase I project will address challenges that electric utilities face in maintaining stability of their grids as more and more intermittent renewable energy generating systems are added to them. Solar and wind are variable and thus complicate the process of balancing energy generation with consumption. The objective of this project is to show the viability of a software-based solution to assist with this balance, reducing the need for expensive energy storage. This service will provide real-time incentives to consumers via their smart phones to reduce or increase electricity usage in response to a request. Another objective is to demonstrate that machine-learning algorithms can help the service estimate consumer response rate based upon environmental, locational, and personal factors. The project will include a preliminary trial with residential electricity consumers where they will be sent requests in response to simulated conditions; some will be able to adjust loads from their smart phones. Electricity usage and other data gathered from the trial will be used to train and test the machine-learning estimators and to evaluate methods that validate whether the consumer performed as promised. 

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be to increase utilities' ability to add renewable electricity generation to their grids while minimizing the need for expensive compensating solutions like gas turbine peaking plants or energy storage. It will also lower peak electricity demand, further reducing the need for peaking plants and therefore reducing costs for utilities and consumers. The end result will be less reliance on fossil fuel for electricity generation, improving the nation's energy security and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. A second impact will be to improve customers' education and engagement with their energy consumption. As a result, consumers may be more likely to purchase and install energy-efficient appliances and home improvements, further reducing energy consumption. An increased technical understanding of that relationship, particularly given the proliferation of smartphones and related applications, will improve the ability to create incentives to foster grid friendly energy consumption.

por.por_cntn:
This project addresses challenges that electric utilities face in maintaining stability of their grids as more and more renewable energy generating systems are added to them. Both wind and solar are intermittent and largely uncontrollable, which complicates the process of balancing electricity supply and demand, in which previously only the demand side was uncontrolled (by the utility, that is). Energy storage can help with the balancing act, but most options are expensive at this time. The objective of this project is to show the viability of a software-based approach that incentivizes residential and small business consumers to help address renewable energy variability. Because it is software, it can be implemented for relatively little cost, thus does not require large capital costs like energy storage systems or new gas turbine generators. The Ikehu Demand Response IncentiVE (DRIVETM) Platform rewards desired consumer behavior with points or airline frequent-flier miles.

The system includes a mobile application to reach consumers through their smart phones with day-of or real-time notifications of incentive offers. These offers could be to reduce, defer, or even increase electricity use for a specified time period, to help the utility match demand to changes in renewable electricity supply (or other grid conditions). The application gives the consumer the option of accepting or rejecting the offer. It also displays his or her energy usage data along with tools to understand the data and tips for reducing electricity bills. Assuming that the user accepts the offer, Ikehu must validate that he or she performed the requested action in order to award airline miles or other points. Validation is done after the fact by accessing the user's smart meter data with the permission of the end consumer and in cooperation with Ikehu's customer, the utility.

Software was developed to contact users with incentives and suggested actions, catalog their responses, and confirm their actions. To demonstrate the technology, gauge its effectiveness, and to collect data necessary for future research, the project included a preliminary trial with residential electricity consumers. Twenty-six participants used the mobile application on their smart phone for 7 weeks at the end of 2013. They were sent incentive offers and asked to change their electricity usage right away in exchange for 100 frequent-flier miles. Each participant's household electricity consumption was monitored for compliance.

The results suggest that the DRIVETM Platform could be a feasible solution to help utilities balance loads. Consumers responded at rates consistent with other energy programs, and changed their usage in the desired direction. The amount of usage change was relatively small, but also consistent with wintertime characteristics in the region. Participants reported wanting to do more, which suggests there is an opportunity for future versions to provide targeted suggestions to help users change behavior. Importantly, the time delay between notification and action was short enough to suggest that the system can be highly valuable to utilities and society as a whole by helping utilities defer or avoid the construction of fast-acting “peaker” power plants. The data collected over the course of the trial will be helpful in the development of technologies that enable the service to contact the right group of consumers with incentives attractive enough to yield the desired electricity consumption shift or reduction.
